Student Directory Staff Directory University of Essex homepage Cunjin Luo People Dr Cunjin Luo Lecturer School of Computer Science and Electronic Engineering (CSEE) Email cunjin.luo@essex.ac.uk Location 3A.523, Colchester Campus Academic support hours 16:00-17:00pm Friday, CSEE 4B.524 (in person); 18:00-19:00pm Monday, Zoom meeting (ID: 8409820103) (online) Profile Research Teaching and supervision Publications Contact Profile Research Teaching and supervision Publications Contact Profile Biography Dr. Cunjin Luo is currently a Lecturer in the School of Computer Science and Electronic Engineering at the University of Essex. He obtained a joint PhD in Computer Science from the Harbin Institute of Technology (HIT) and the University of Manchester (UoM). He is a member of IEEE, a Fellow of the Higher Education Academy, and serves as an Academic Editor for PLOS Digital Health, PLOS ONE, BMC Medical Informatics and Decision Making, and Frontiers in Physiology. Dr. Luo’s research spans two closely related domains: cardiac modelling and biomedical simulation, and security in healthcare and medical information systems. In cardiac modelling, his work focuses on computational analyses of arrhythmogenic conditions, particularly various forms of short QT syndrome associated with ion channel mutations such as KCNJ2 and KCNQ1. He has conducted simulation-based studies on the effects of anti-arrhythmic drugs (including quinidine, disopyramide, E-4031, and amiodarone) on ventricular electrophysiology and re-entrant excitation dynamics. His contributions also include research on mechanisms underlying T-wave alternans, atrial remodelling, and other cardiac abnormalities. In the field of healthcare informatics and system security, Dr. Luo has investigated human factors and incident-response processes within healthcare information environments. His work covers employee perceptions of human error in security practices, proactive and agile incident-response frameworks (e.g., IS-CHEC), as well as defence strategies for intelligent medical diagnosis systems. Additionally, he has explored the application of AI-driven ethical hacking techniques in the protection of health information infrastructures. Overall, Dr. Luo’s research integrates biomedical engineering with healthcare IT security, bridging physiological system modelling and the protection of modern medical technologies. His work is distinguished by its emphasis on practical, simulation-driven insights and real-world solutions to emerging challenges in healthcare and clinical informatics.
